{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3629519,"name":"Kabir","username":"kn4","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kn4/{size}/235296_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-19T23:39:31.584Z","cooked":"

Past years’ usage reporting data shows a decreasing amount of teams using LabVIEW:

PhotonVision Offseason Development 2024 PhotonVision
This graph is 4 years old. Here’s data from 2024 usage reporting: [2024-lang-usage-percent-projected] [2024-lang-usage-totals] Year Java LabVIEW C++ Python C# Kotlin Unknown Totals 2016 1526 1116 435 33 1 0 3 3114 2017 1873 979 428 43 6 0 2 3331 2018 2280 862 408 64 0 0 2 3616 2019 2595 709 371 77 0 0 8 3760 2020 1527 288 158 31 0 4 0 2008 2022 2479 277 249 46 0 2 0 3053 2023 2833 181 216 53 0 1 0 3284 2024 3099 93 176 92 0 13 1 3474

In fact, extrapolating with a linear model, we would expect a negative number of teams using LabVIEW this season!

With its currently uncertain status for 2027, I’m wondering which teams used LabVIEW in 2025 and why they did so. Was it primarily just due to familiarity? Have any teams recently switched to LabVIEW from another language? Feel free to answer if you know about a local team who might not check here regularly.

For anyone who knows, in what specific instances or scenarios does LabVIEW outperform Java, C++, or Python? I’ve heard it easily provides live telemetry but I haven’t personally seen any specific examples.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-19T23:39:31.584Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":25,"reads":506,"readers_count":505,"score":291.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Kabir","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/photonvision-offseason-development-2024/469436/14","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"PhotonVision Offseason Development 2024","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57470,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2724 programmer"},"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3629531,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-19T23:55:39.301Z","cooked":"

Of the 4 officially supported languages, there’s really very little (if anything) that distinguishes one over the others, at least as far as performance goes. Realistically, it comes down to what you know and what your mentors can support. Areas with a significant NI/Emerson presence are likely to have employee mentors, who in turn are likely to better support labview. For these teams, it makes sense to use it. For everyone else, it makes sense to choose the language with the best documentation and support (including 3rd-party tools), which has been java for quite a while now.

I don’t think LabView really makes sense for any team regardless of context/mentor specialty in the year 2025.

I wish this would carry over to industry. Half the systems of research projects in college had labview.

I never said it was a good decision, just that it made sense for those teams to have chosen it. “Makes sense” in this context meaning “there is a logical thought process”. A decision can be both logical and incorrect.

jedgar6:

had labview.

Every machine in the area I work in at Bridgestone has a NI/Labview stuff attached to it for monitoring certain processes

I very much avoid telling anyone that I know how to use that software

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T01:50:56.206Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":358,"readers_count":357,"score":141.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Off to California I go..."},"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3629629,"name":"Landonh12","username":"Landonh12","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/landonh12/{size}/259949_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T02:14:28.786Z","cooked":"

2468, 2687, and 2689 used LabVIEW in 2025. We have mentors who know it well (I used LV as a student in FRC, Greg and Joe work at NI). Our students have generational knowledge in LV. And we have lots of reusable code and internal tooling in LV. We have our own path planner written in LabVIEW, own swerve library, etc.

Is it the best solution? I would imagine the vast majority of FRC programmers would say no due to the lack of publicly available code and tooling alongside the language itself.
We do deal with some of the drawbacks - code readability, deploy times, windows requirement, etc. are some of the areas of difficulty. However, it provides our students with an opportunity to really dig in and write code and tools from scratch. It works for us and we have had success with it.

We are exploring other options should LV not exist in 2027.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T02:22:26.173Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":230.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Landonh12","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":9}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17818,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2689 Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3629660,"name":"Joshua J","username":"thatnameistaken","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T02:26:27.432Z","cooked":"
kn4:

For anyone who knows, in what specific instances or scenarios does LabVIEW outperform Java, C++, or Python? I’ve heard it easily provides live telemetry but I haven’t personally seen any specific examples.

You haven’t seen examples because it’s no longer particularly relevant in FRC. If you want to know what it’s capable of, imagine being able to highlight any function in a line of code and see what it was evaluating live in real time as the program looped. Additionally, it’s very easy to set up charts to graph this data if needed.

If you’re thinking “that sounds useful but we kinda have that already with Network Tables and dashboard programs”, you’re imagining almost exactly what this easy telemetry got you. A combination of so many things being CAN, the big CAN vendors having auto data logging solutions, and AdvantageScope have largely eliminated this gap, with what little remains not being a big deal to set up in network tables manually. I was tuning PID loops using live rolling graphs of the sensor feedback and setpoint as a student 10 years ago and that was genuinely an advantage back then, but it’s basically how WPILib’s documentation shows you to do it now and it’s easy in any language.

Just the fact that you have to roll your own swerve library alone is enough to make it a poor fit for the average team nowadays. There’s nothing inherently broken about LabVIEW, and if there was some sort of FRC-adjacent competition for adults that used NI hardware I’d strongly consider using it due to my own personal familiarity with it, both in competitive robotics (FRC) and professionally.

But in an educational environment, it no longer makes much sense.

JohnFogarty:

I very much avoid telling anyone that I know how to use that software

The rest of us appreciate the extra job security

I essentially got hired specifically due to my familiarity with NI software after my company gave up on letting CS majors with no LV background figure it out on the fly.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T02:28:29.222Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":307,"readers_count":306,"score":101.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Joshua J","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19116,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CSA | Drive Coach (2191)"},"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3629855,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T04:22:21.914Z","cooked":"

I used it one year back in 2018

Started a new team and that was the only language I knew how to use for FRC. It’s unreasonably slow, 2+ minute compile and deploy. No quick changes at all

But, it worked and ultimately I think it was the right decision for that year. Every year since, we’ve used Java

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T04:22:21.914Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":247,"readers_count":246,"score":49.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Chadfrom7226","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20021,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3629860,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T04:41:10.267Z","cooked":"
JohnFogarty:

I very much avoid telling anyone that I know how to use that software

Very often when I tell people who work in industrial automation or autonomous vehicles about FRC, and it comes up that the controller is made by NI, they ask if Labview is the/one of the supported languages for the competition. What follows is usually a tirade about how much they hate Labview.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T04:41:10.267Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":237,"readers_count":236,"score":92.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Rahul Yarlagadda","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7457 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/10","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3629999,"name":"Nick Seidl","username":"Nick_Seidl","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nick_seidl/{size}/454_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T13:17:27.841Z","cooked":"

We are switching to Java for next year, but we’ve been a LabView team for a few years. I think the decision was originally made many years ago because someone assumed (incorrectly) that because of its graphical nature it was akin to FLL and easier to learn.

We had some mentor turnover over the years, and at one point the only mentor we had with programming experience was a mechanical engineer who had to learn LabView for some side quest at work. He recently asked to be relieved of his programming duties (is still an engineering mentor with us), so we are in the process of trying to recruit someone who can do Java.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T13:17:27.841Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":181,"readers_count":180,"score":36.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Nick Seidl","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1438,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2867 Nerd-in-Chief"},"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/11","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3630021,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T13:26:36.422Z","cooked":"
Landonh12:

However, it provides our students with an opportunity to really dig in and write code and tools from scratch.

Could you explain how your team’s use of LabView helps with this, in particular?

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T13:26:36.422Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":170,"readers_count":169,"score":69.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/12","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3630052,"name":"Mike","username":"Mike_FRC_56","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_frc_56/{size}/178961_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T13:47:17.699Z","cooked":"

While we’ve been Java for a bit now, we used LabView until around 2018.

I liked using it because you didn’t have to understand a programming language in order to use it. It’s not a huge percentage of FRC students that go on to careers where they write code for a living. I know there are some who will and those students get a huge benefit from experience with a real-time control system with Java or C++ or Python. However, even if you’re probably not going to be writing huge amounts of code after high school, there are problem-solving, critical thinking and hardware-coordination skills that programming helps you learn. The beauty of programming and automation is that the robot doesn’t know what’s going on in the real world – it will only do the things you tell it to do given the very small amount of information you tell it to look at. Getting students to think that way without having to worry about “how do I write this in Java” was a benefit to us with LabView.

Now there were lots of weird things about LabView that are made so much easier with traditional languages and we’d never go back, but I do miss the way that LabView let our students think about programming – as a flow of information into specific things and the outputs which flow out of them – as compared to Java. To be fair, the command-based programming in Java does get to some that but it was nice to be able to see it visually instead of having to know Java first before you could understand what the code was doing.

For us old folks, it was a nice shift when we moved from C++ to Labview back in the olden days. High schools didn’t teach C++ so a more graphical programming style did seem easier. Now that students take Java or Python in high school so they have some exposure before working on an FRC robot, there is less of that benefit and the power and ubiquity of these languages and the community-based tools for them means LabView feels a lot like pneumatics (was useful 15 years ago, not really a ton of utility now given the other options available)

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T13:48:40.189Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":50.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Mike","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50093,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/13","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3630053,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T13:50:08.816Z","cooked":"
Mike_FRC_56:

I do miss the way that LabView let our students think about programming – as a flow of information into specific things and the outputs which flow out of them

I think dataflow languages are cool, but outside of pure signal-processing environments i think they’re mostly useful when paired with a text-based language for things that can’t be visually represented so neatly in 2 dimensions (which you almost certainly will encounter).

I hope we eventually get a good tool for visual command composition. I’ve seen several community examples of block-based command code generators that look promising.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-05-20T13:50:49.340Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":27.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":502064,"topic_slug":"labview-teams-why","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/labview-teams-why/502064/14","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3630055,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T13:52:12.557Z","cooked":"

This isn’t what the OP asked, but we left LabVIEW largely because of the online documentation and tools that JAVA has in the FRC space.

People cite a lack of pre-written code in LabVIEW, but that’s mostly incorrect. There are (and have been since perhaps 2017/2018) swerve projects, path planning, and within the last 3 years a complete port of WPILib.

However, LabView isn’t taught in school, the FRC LabView community isn’t large, and the resources aren’t obvious unless you know the other teams who do LabView and have contacts with them to ask questions.

Landonh12:

We are exploring other options should LV not exist in 2027.

I wonder if anyone has tried to use Simulink/MATLAB EmbeddedCoder to generate FRC-compatible C++? At least in my industry (automotive) model-based code in Simulink is a whole lot more common than anything NI. We have some little data collection systems that use a cRIO, but all the product work is hand code or generated-from-Simulink C/C++.

There was actually a MatLab/Simulink beta test for writing FRC software back in 2011 or so. It never made it to competition use as far as I know.

Even if you find reinventing the wheel to be a good thing (I think it can have good learning value but I don’t think it’s generally a good idea for teams) you could do it much easier and also give the programmers more useful learning by using a more mainstream language. In more mainstream languages, the students can learn how to work with build systems that they might encounter in their future, understand how to work with common programming patterns rather than the LabVIEW programming patterns, and work with third-party libraries developed by open-source projects.
